trebor

A new fossil form the Jurassic time has basically is causing scientist to rethink the roll of mammals in the Jurassic times. IT seems that with this fossil, they were in a greater roll than previously thought.
 
 http://www.cnn.com/2006/TECH/science/02/23/jurassic.beaver.ap/index.html
 
 [qs]
 - For years the mammals living in the era of dinosaurs have been thought of as tiny shrew-like creatures scurrying through the underbrush. Now the discovery of a furry aquatic creature with seal-like teeth and a flat tail like a beaver has demolished that image.
 [/qs]

post_info.post_title: Jurassic beaver' turns theory on its tail

Tastyfish

This is good news for DNA dating as well, its been pretty much expected that mammals would have been around a lot longer than we think in forms other than just rat things. Whenever organisms thought to be common ancestors of modern organisms are dated using comparisons between DNA, the dates are always close but tend to give a result a few million years older.

That is interesting. As far as the mammals that look like prehistoric dogs, what was the size of the dinosaurs that they fed on? I may have missed something. That would almost be weird if the dinos were about 5-10 times larger than them. However, if they are the ancestors of dogs, that might explain some dogs like my own who tries to go up against dogs larger and taller than him but gets scared away by dogs smaller than him. But besides that, could it also be that they were scavengers? I was just wondering if that was a possibility.
 Also, anyone else notice that both of those mammals (the dog-like one and the beaver) were both found in China? Is there any more to this or just a coincidence?
daewoo

 It did not have a full grown T-rex in its stomach. At first they mistook it for an embryo. That would suggest pretty heavily that it was either newly hatched, or the dog ate the egg.
C. Langana

There were some dinosaurs about the size of a contemporary chicken, from wikipedia: "the smallest dinosaurs known were about the size of a crow or a chicken. The Microraptor, Parvicursor, and Saltopus were all under 60 cm (2 ft) in length." So a juvenile one of those might be quite easy to swallow whole. 
 
 Ooaman The china thing is coincidence, certain parts of the area have good geological conditions for finding fossils IIRC.
 
 Linkage:http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dinosaur#Size
beervolcano

It's interesting that all of these fossils that have been "rewriting textbooks" in the past decade or so all came from China. The feathered dinosaurs, the primitive birds, the large jurassic mammals, and even Precambrian fossils of primitive chordates all came from China.
pandion

It's interesting that all of these fossils that have been "rewriting textbooks" in the past decade or so all came from China. The feathered dinosaurs, the primitive birds, the large jurassic mammals, and even Precambrian fossils of primitive chordates all came from China.
Yes, but China hasn't been available for paleontological research for the last 50 years or so, with the exception of the "Peking Man" site from which additional Homo erectus fossils were recovered shortly after WWII. In recent years, more and more foreign paleontologists have been allowed into China, along with some excellent Chinese paleontologists (mostly foreign trained). There is too, the fact that China covers a pretty large area.
C. Langana

Coupled with "China in particular has produced many exceptional feathered dinosaur specimens due to the unique geology of its dinosaur beds, as well as an ancient arid climate particularly conducive to fossilization."
